description: African music is a vast and diverse field, with distinct traditions across its many regions. It is characterized by complex polyrhythms, call-and-response patterns, and a deep connection to social and ceremonial life.

regions.name: West Africa
regions.description: Known for its rich drumming traditions, griot storytellers, and the origins of blues and jazz. Music is deeply integrated into community life.

regions.name: North Africa (Maghreb)
regions.description: Characterized by its strong connections to Arabic and Andalusian music traditions, featuring microtonal scales (maqamat) and complex rhythmic patterns.

regions.name: Central Africa
regions.description: Dominated by vocal music, often featuring intricate polyphonic singing and interlocking rhythmic parts. Soukous is a major popular genre from this region.

regions.name: East Africa
regions.description: A crossroads of African, Arabic, and Indian influences. Taarab music is a notable example of this fusion.

regions.name: Southern Africa
regions.description: Known for its powerful vocal harmonies, as heard in Isicathamiya and Mbube styles. Also home to genres like Kwaito and Amapiano.
